ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PORT OF SINGAPORE AUTHORITY
WHARVES AT TANJONG PAGAR
(Reduction in usage and effects)


    1. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Communications if he will ascertain from the Port of Singapore Authority (a) in respect of the Authority's wharves at Tanjong Pagar, for the first quarter of 1972 and the corresponding period of 1971 -

    (i) the aggregate number and tonnage of vessels that were berthed at those wharves;

    (ii) the aggregate tonnage of cargo loaded on and off the vessels so berthed;

    (iii) the aggregate revenue of the Authority arising from the berthing of the vessels and the handling of cargo loaded on and off the vessels: and

Column: 1306



    (iv) the aggregate number of man-days put in by the Authority's employees in relation to the berthing of the vessels and the handling of cargo loaded on and off the vessels; and

(b) the explanation for the reduction in the usage of the Authority's wharves at Tanjong Pagar; and whether the Authority is taking any steps to rectify the loss of potential revenue to the Authority and to alleviate the hardship of the Authority's employees who have suffered a reduction in take-home pay consequent upon the reduced usage of those wharves.

    

    The Acting Minister for Communications (Dr Toh Chin Chye): The take-home pay of Port of Singapore Authority workers for the first quarter of 1972 was affected slightly. The cause is partly because of the new tariffs. However, there are other factors such as the decline in trade between Japan and the United States with the rest of the world.

Column: 1307

The PSA is watching the position closely and will take every measure to ensure that no hardship will be caused to its workers.

    (a) In respect of the PSA wharves at Tanjong Pagar for the first quarter of 1972 and the corresponding period of 1971:-

    (i) 999 ships with a tonnage of 3.79 million NRT were berthed in 1972, as compared with 1,032 ships with 3.54 million NRT for the same period in 1971;

    (ii) 2.31 million tonnes of cargo (including general, fuel and bulk) were loaded on and off these vessels in 1972, as compared with 2.53 million tonnes for the same period in 1971;

    (iii) total revenue, including port dues, pilot age and dock dues, wharf labour revenue, storage rent, wharf age and other revenues connected with these ships and cargo handled amounted to $34.39 million for the period January to March 1972, as compared with $24.229 million for the same period in 1971;

    (iv) PSA figures for work done by its employees at the wharf are not kept in terms of man-days but in terms of gang-hours. For the first quarter of 1972 the total gang-hours worked amounted to 99,530, as compared with 131,949 for the same period in 1971.

    (b) The reduction in the usage of the PSA wharves at Tanjong Pagar is one of the objectives of the new tariffs introduced with effect from 1st January, 1972. The new tariffs ensured that there will be more effective utilisation of the wharves, less congestion, quicker working of cargoes and more expeditious turn-round time of ships. Average turn-round time per vessel dropped from 49X hours in 1971 to 39 hours in 1972. Average waiting time for a berth dropped from five hours in 1971 to one and a quarter hours in 1972. These are being achieved with no loss in revenue at all.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): From the answer, it is obvious that there is a reduction in workload resulting in a reduction in take-home pay. Sir, can

Column: 1308

the Minister tell the House what concrete steps has the PSA taken to alleviate this hardship arising out of the reduction in the take-home pay? Also as a result of the reduction of workload, will there be any redundancy in PSA amongst the employees?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, there has been no reduction at all in take-home pay because of the improved productivity. What has happened, of course, is that the port workers earn a full month's wages for working 19 to 20 days of the month, and for the rest of the month they go on holiday. I think this is the reason for the impression that there has been a reduced workload at the port. However, since 1964 the PSA has guaranteed its daily-rated port workers a monthly minimum earning computed under an arithmetical formula of 26 times the sum of the individual worker's daily basic salary, plus his cost of living allowance, average shift allowance payable, plus 30 times his daily housing allowance. This minimum earning does not include any incentive bonus payment, which is dependent on productivity.

    I would like to add this further information to assure the Member for Telok Blangah that the integrated gang labour during the first quarter of this year had an average of 25 days' work, and most of them earned either more or less than what they earned last year. For the period January to March 1972, as compared with the same period for 1971, out of a total of 2,122 integrated gang labourers, 1,376 had increased earnings whilst 746 had decreased earnings. The port and shipping industry is an industry in which there can be no consistent level of work. On some days, more work is performed above the average requirements, while on other days there are shortfalls. It is for this reason that the PSA has resorted to a pool of casual labour who could be asked to supplement the normal labour force on those occasions when the demand for labour exceeds the supply, and who also act as substitutes for permanent labourers who are on leave or absent.

Column: 1309



    Casual labourers consist of unemployed workers registered with the Ministry of Labour and also with the Pont Authority. The registration of these casual labourers does not imply that the PSA will automatically offer them work daily. But on those days when the casual labourers report and offer themselves for work and should there be no work, a payment of $1 is made to each worker so as to assist him to recover his travelling expenses. The present poo1 of casual labourers has been on the register since February 1971. The total number is about 424 as at the end of March 1972.

    During the first quarter of 1972, no casual labourer has less than 14 days' work in a month. In fact, casual labourers have an average of 19 days' work per month. However, it is the policy of the Port Authority to gradually ease out the pool of casual labourers into the general labour pool, and this should be so particularly at this moment when there is a shortage of labour in Singapore, and it is important that we should not keep such a large pool of casual labour around the port. But after consultation with representatives on the Board, we have agreed that the pool should be eased off gradually so as to enable the casual labourers to re-adjust themselves to another form of work.

    What I have said, Mr Speaker, points out the fact that the improved methods which have been adopted at the Port have increased productivity, and the fact that the average worker is earning a month's salary in half the time that he used to do should ordinarily be regarded as a boom to the industry. But it is unfortunate that at this period when there is a recession in world trade, particularly between Japan and the United States, the slack or the leisure time which should have been occupied in fruitful work has not been made available. I am afraid the Port Authority is not responsible for this, as it is not in control of the world economic situation. However, I would like to assure the Member for Telok Blangah that no gang labour registered with the Port Authority will be regarded as redundant labour.

Column: 1310



    Mr N. Govindasamy: Just one more supplementary question, Sir, lf, by the increased output of the workers, they are able to earn 20 days' wages for work which they would normally perform in 16 days, as the Minister has said just now, would the PSA guarantee 26 days' wages as they had been promised, irrespective of the fact whether work is available for them or not? In respect of easing out casual labourers who are just staying behind and doing nothing, when is it going to take place?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I have in my answer earlier, Mr Speaker, said that this has been going on since 1964, and the PSA has assured these daily-rated port workers a monthly minimum earning which has been computed 26 times the sum of the individual worker's basic salary, plus cost of living allowance, shift allowance, housing allowance, and so on. This is still going on.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, if the vessels are not berthed alongside the wharves, how can the labourer get more pay? So many vessels are in the outer roads discharging cargo by putting it into lighters which then take it to the wharves. Sir, will the Minister take action to see that no ship must be allowed to unload in outer roads, but must come alongside the wharves? Only then will the labourers get more work and more pay.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, the answer to the statement made by the Member for Anson is an English quotation which says that "You can take a horse to the water, but you cannot make him drink". The reason why the port worker earns more money is due to the increased tariffs, although there are even fewer number of ships coming in. I think that gives him the right answer.

PEOPLE'S ASSOCIATION
(Sports promotion through community centres)


    2. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Culture if the People's Association will give full support to the National Sports Promotion Board by mobilising all its resources at the community centres in bringing about a new milieu in sports in the Republic.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker. Sir, there :s large scope for co-operation between the National Sports Promotion Board and the People's Association in respect of promoting and organising sporting activities. The National Sports Promotion Board has been established to encourage, develop and promote sports on a national basis, whilst the People's Association has, among its objectives, the responsibility of organising and promoting group participation in social, cultural, educational and athletic activities for the people of Singapore.

    It can be seen that the People's Association cannot mobilise all its resources at the community centres just for the promotion of athletic activities, as the role of the People's Association embraces a much wider scope. However, the Association will be willing to contribute its share in bringing about a new milieu in sports in the Republic. The Director of the People's Association is currently a member of the Board of Directors of the National Sports Promotion Board and close co-ordination between the two organisations can be expected.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister indicate in what way can the People's Association contribute towards this objective?

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: It can contribute, for instance, by allowing the ordinary use of the community centre premises. Apart from that, very much depends on the sports organisations and the management committees of the community centres in the respective constituencies.

CHARLTON PARK AREA
(Building of public swimming pool)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting -

    3. To ask the Minister for Social Affairs, as there is no public swimming pool in the rural and suburban areas, if he will consider the request of the Member of Parliament for Upper Serangoon that a swimming pool be built as soon as possible in the Charlton Park area because of the large number of primary and secondary schools in the vicinity of that area.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Hwang Soo Jin.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Question No. 3. Sir.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, in new residential areas, adequate sports facilities have been included as part of the overall requirement of community services. Admittedly, there are older residential areas, including outlying areas of Singapore, for which sports facilities are still lacking. Both the Ministry of National Development and the Ministry of Social Affairs are aware of the need to plan for more sports facilities in these areas but these must be based on the felt needs of the people.

    Increasing emphasis will be placed in the future in providing more sports and recreation facilities to meet the requirements for such facilities as more and more people take to leisure and the competitive sports as spectators and participants. It is, therefore, proposed to set up a committee comprising representatives of the Ministries of Social Affairs, National Development and Education and the National Sports Promotion Board to make an overall review of the requirements for sports facilities in relation to the Singapore population and on geographic and demographic considerations and to relate the results to general policy and planning.

    As regards a swimming pool for the Charlton Park area, the Minister for Law and National Development has indicated to me that his Ministry would

Column: 1313

be prepared to give every due consideration to the proposal, and the National Sports Promotion Board has been requested to look into the request with a view to ascertaining that there is a real need for the facility and that it will be fully utilised by the people in the area.

CHILDREN'S CENTRES AND CRECHES
(Adequacy of)


    4. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Social Affairs (a) what are the activities carried on in children's centres and creches; and (b) if the number of creches presently run by his Ministry is adequate; whether there are plans for the opening of new creches; and if one of those creches can be situated in a locality convenient for the use of residents in the Tanjong Rhu Housing Estate.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Social Welfare Department is currently operating eight children's centres. These centres provide elementary education and training for non-school going children between the ages of five and 15 years. In addition to classroom work, the children are taught arts and crafts, basketry. sewing and carpentry, physical training, games and kindergarten activities depending on their age. They are given one light meal a day and are provided with regular medical and dental care. The Social Welfare Department, working in close liaison with the Ministry of Education, also looks into the arrangements for the admission of the children into regular schools. In 197!. 489 children have been so admitted. As the number of non-school going children is on the decline and as the People's Association is operating a large number of kindergarten classes, there is a diminishing need for children's centres. The Social Welfare Department, therefore, has no plan to expand this programme.

    The Department also operates ii creches. These creches offer a day-care service for young children so as to enable their parents to give of their

Column: 1314

best while at work. The nutritious meals provided in the creches will help overcome malnutrition among young children of working parents and the kindergarten training given to them will give them a better start in life.

    For our present needs, the 11 existing creches and two more under construction - one in Toa Payoh New Town Centre and the other in the Kallang Industrial Estate - would appear to be adequate. In its long-term planning, however, the Social Welfare Department has included the establishment of creches in Queenstown and other Housing and Development Board estates where there is a high concentration of working mothers. The Department will look into the need for setting up a creche in the Katong/Tanjong Rhu area for possible inclusion in the Housing and Development Board's plans for the development of the reclaimed land along the East Coast of Singapore.

    Additionally, the Government is encouraging the private sector, particularly the industrial establishments, to provide creches where there are a large number of working mothers as employees.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker. Sir, can the Minister tell us how long it will take for the long-term development plan that he has described to mature in respect of the development of more creches'? This need is especially felt in view of our intention to encourage more women to join the work force.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry I cannot tell the Member off-hand. It is a long-term policy. I personally would like to see the creches built as soon as possible. However, there is the question of funds, and also other aspects have to be considered.

WOODLANDS NEW TOWN
(Facilities and amenities)


    5. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Law and National Development to give details of the proposed educational, social and other facilities and amenities that will be provided by the Housing and Development Board in the new Woodlands New Town now being built.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, under Stage I of the new town development, 15,000 flats for about 75,000 people will be built in Woodlands. A large commercial centre with shopping facilities, cinemas, cooked food centres and parking facilities for vehicles awaiting customs clearance will be developed near the Customs and Immigration check point at the Causeway. A post office, a maternity and child health centre, a creche, a Public Utilities Board collection centre, a commercial hall and an area office of the Housing and Development Board will also be provided.

    Woodlands New Town, to be developed by the Housing and Development Board over a period of about 15 years, will eventually cover an area of about 2,500 acres. Most of the residents in the satellite town will be employed in the industrial and other economic activities within and around the township. Residential development will follow the neighbourhood principle, similar to that in Queenstown and Toa Payoh. A market and cooked-food centre will be provided in the shopping centre of each neighbourhood. Sites for schools will be set aside for primary, secondary and vocational education. A few community centres will be built in each neighbourhood, together with sports and recreational facilities.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Training and educational facilities for Estate Officers)


    6. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board what training and educational facilities are afforded Estate Officers in order to equip them for improved performance as well as help them in their career development.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board has two training schemes for its Estate Officers. Those with the Higher School Certificate undergo an in-service training programme before taking the external examinations of the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors (R. I. C. S.) to become professionally qualified and eligible for promotion to senior officers. Those with University degrees also undergo an in-service training programme in order to enable them to attain the professional qualification of the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors. These graduates are exempted from appearing for the first professional examination of the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors.

    Mr Conceicao: Mr Speaker, Sir, among the courses for Estate Officers would the Minister also consider including courses in public relations, so that unnecessary misunderstanding between the Housing Board officials and the public may be avoided?

    Mr Barker: These courses form part of their training. However, in view of the Member's comment, I will look further into these allegations.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes.

    A full list of all licensed chit fund companies will be published in the Government Gazette annually in the month of April. In between, my Ministry will make periodic announcements of newly-licensed chit fund companies.

MEDICAL (THERAPY, EDUCATION AND RESEARCH) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read,

4.00 p.m.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Medical (Therapy, Education and Research) Act, 1965, (now Cap. 160 of the Revised Edition) was passed by Parliament on 31st December, 1965, and was brought into operation on 7th

Column: 1340

January, 1966. It embodied two objectives:

    (i) To allow under certain circumstances the removal of organs or tissues or the examination of the body after death. Such procedures could be undertaken when the person before death had expressly stated a desire that his body at death be used for any of the purposes of the Act. In the absence of any stated wishes of the person before death, the relatives could give the necessary consent for the procedures to be carried out.

    (ii) To provide sufficient safeguards to ensure that the freely expressed wishes of a person are carried out. If there was a specific wish to donate his eyes or an organ, this would be carried out. Conversely, if there was a specific objection by the person no such procedures would be carried out.

    The safeguards, however, went further, primarily for goodwill, that no such procedures could be carried out even if the person had explicitly wanted it before his death, if there was any objection by any surviving relative.

    Almost from the onset it became apparent that there was a conflict in the purposes of the Act. As a result, it has not been as successful in its application in promoting the purposes of medical advancement. Because of the stringent provisions and ambiguities, there have been instances where the hospital failed to obtain organs from a dead person despite his having given consent before death or despite consent of his relatives having been given.

    Perhaps this was the result of insufficient experience and over-caution at the time when the Act was framed. At that time the only transplantation operation routinely done in Singapore was the corneal transplant. Kidney transplant operations had not been quite perfected nor yet undertaken in Singapore. There was, therefore, little experience to fall back on in the drafting of the Act. The rapid advances in medical science and technology had in the meantime overtaken the legal provisions of the Act.

    One defect of the Act soon became apparent. To ensure the success of the transplant, the tissue must be removed from the dead body as soon as possible after death. The legal provisions as provided by the Act do not allow this to be done because of the formal procedures to be taken. Some of these provisions are, worse still, quite ambiguous. Another defect is that the law allows any surviving relative to forbid a donation with the result that the hospital is unable to comply with the wishes of the donor who made them before death. The serious defects in the Act may be listed as follows:

    (i) There is no definition of what is meant by any "surviving relative". There is no precedent to fall back on. Hence it could happen, even though this is only a theoretical possibility, that any relative, no matter how far removed, could come forward to object to the operation being conducted. This actually occurred in the famous case of the death of the American authoress, Grace Metalious, who had specifically willed her body to a medical school. But this was forbidden by her next-of-kin. The resultant controversy led to an amendment to the law of the State of Massachusetts.

    (ii) As illustrated by the example I have just given, the properly stated wishes of the person may be overruled by some relative at death.

    (iii) The phrases, that "such reasonable enquiries as may be practicable" must be made by "the person in lawful possession of the body of a deceased" to see whether any of the surviving relatives (who are not defined) object to the gift, are ambiguous. The vagueness of these provisions is especially deplorable in view of how critical it is that in transplant operations the time lag between donor's death and the operation should be kept as short as possible. A good deal of time is lost in going around sounding every relative to find out whether or not he or she objects to the use of the body for the purposes of the Act.

Column: 1342



    The phrase "the person in lawful possession of the body of a deceased" is invoked in the case where no specific statement has been made by the deceased before death. In which case the person lawfully in possession of his body can give consent. However, under the present law it is not possible to say with any degree of certainty who such a person is. There has, therefore, been much debate over the interpretation of the words "person in lawful possession". It was originally used by the draftsman of the Anatomy Act of the United Kingdom of 1832. This was a piece of legislation passed in the aftermath of the ghoulish activities of the body snatchers of Burke and Hare. The words were interpreted to include the Master of Workhouses and likewise the Board of Management of a hospital where an individual dies. This appears, however, to have been restricted now as not to include the hospital management but executors or close relatives of the deceased.

    In the United Kingdom, the corresponding law known as the Human Tissue Act, 1961, on which our own Act was modelled on, had also been found to be inadequate. Like our Act, it was supposed to be comprehensive and to provide a charter for the advancement of medicine, research and education. It had replaced a preceding Act known as the Corneal Grafting Act of 1952 and an earlier Act known as the Anatomy Act, 1832. It was probably on the models of these previous Acts that the ambiguous term "person in lawful possession" had come down through to our present Act.

    Because of this evident defect, the Health Minister in the United Kingdom in January 1969 formed an advisory group on transplant problems to make recommendations on amendments, if any, to the Human Tissue Act, 1961.

    In the United States of America the corresponding law is known as the Uniform Anatomical Gift Act. It is the product of three years of intensive study by a special committee of the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State laws. It had considered

Column: 1343

earlier drafts and reviews by medical and scientific groups and also received the endorsement of the American Bar Association.

    Rather than touch up our existing Act with amendments here and there, it was decided to repeal it and replace it with an entirely new Bill modelled on the United States Uniform Anatomical Gift Act.

    The present Bill before the House has, therefore, two purposes, namely, the repeal of the existing Act and its re-enactment. The objectives and scope of its provision remain the same while the operation of its provisions is now made clear and is without ambiguity.

    It is designed to facilitate the donation and use of human tissues and organs for transplant operations and other medical purposes and provides favourable legal provisions for such activities.

    To make its full beneficial impact on the community the purpose for which such anatomical gifts can be made, the provisions have been extended to include education and the advancement of dental science. The existing Act has no reference to dentistry. The salient points in the Bill are as follows:

    (i) It permits the removal of an organ or the use of the body or parts of the body for examination or for medical education where a person has specifically willed it in writing or orally in the presence of two or more witnesses. A safeguard is provided for revocation of the gift by the donor at any time.

    (ii) Where no specific wish has been expressed to make a donation of parts of a body or for a medical examination of the dead person, authority to do so may be given by relatives or by the Director of the Medical Institution if the body is not claimed after 24 hours.

    The safeguard here is that if it is known that the person had specifically objected to such procedures, then the procedures cannot be carried out.

    The provisions in the Bill which differ from those in the existing Act are as follows:

Column: 1344



    (i) Omission of all references to the ambiguous expressions, such as "persons in lawful possession" and "having made such enquiries as may be practicable".

    (ii) And, this is more important, that the donor's wish takes primacy over all others. In the existing Act, any relative may forbid the removal or examination of the body and can thus veto the wishes of the deceased.

    (iii) So as to avoid ambiguity as to which surviving relative or person who could legally authorise removal of parts of a body or the carrying out of a post-mortem, the Bill lists the relatives who may give valid consent in an order of precedence. By this, the wishes of a relative in a higher order in the list will take precedence over those relatives in a lower order.

    Here again, a safeguard has been written into the provisions in that, if there be any conflict between relatives in the same order of priority, the authority to examine or remove parts of the body will not be given.

    I should, however, like to mention that although it may be desirable to make this law as comprehensive as possible, we have deliberately not touched on the point concerning the removal of an organ from a living donor. In fact, there is no need to do so because within the medical services and profession there are codes of conduct which govern medical practice and which lay down rules on determining death, obtaining consent for donation of tissues and for the examination of bodies.

    At the present stage of medical development in Singapore, the provisions as embodied in the Bill together with the safeguards should be sufficient to enable the use of the body or parts of a body for transplants and the advancement of medical knowledge, education and research.

DANGEROUS FIREWORKS BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

4.21 p.m.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. Wong Lin Ken): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill is the result of a series of mishaps which could have been prevented, and the Bill made unnecessary, if some sections of the public had been co-operative and had acted with good sense and restraint. Permit me, Sir, briefly to recount the circumstances that finally led the Government, with the support of public opinion, to introduce this Bill, which, I do not doubt, this House will fully endorse.

    The firing of crackers is an ancient Chinese custom, rooted in beliefs no longer credible among the better educated, but, nevertheless, remaining an enjoyable way of celebrating Chinese festive occasions, like the Chinese New Year. Other communities have also taken up the firing of crackers but not the beliefs. However, the firing of crackers has always presented the problem of fire hazards, which have increased, as the explosive ingredients are improved by modern scientific knowledge. In addition, hazards of physical injuries also have become a problem.

    It will be recalled that, in February 1970, during the Chinese New Year festival, there was indiscriminate letting off of fire-crackers. As a result, there were six deaths, 68 injured, and S361,000 worth of damage to property. There was public concern, and the Parliamentary Secretary for Social Affairs announced in this Parliament, on the 9th of March of the same year, that all firing of

Column: 1347

crackers would be prohibited in future, unless permits were first obtained from the Police. During festive occasions, like Chinese New Year's eve and Chap Goh Meh, the firing of crackers would be permitted for adults in certain defined areas, and within specified hours.

    Section 6 of the Minor Offences Act was amended to enforce this policy. In substance, this amendment imposes a general prohibition on the discharge of fire-crackers and fireworks. The Deputy Commissioner of Police, or his authorised representative, is empowered to lift this general prohibition, either by way of a Gazette notification, or by the issue of licences to individuals or public bodies, provided the discharge of fire-crackers or fireworks takes place in the areas, and within the time limits, stipulated by the Police.

    The Minor Offences (Amendment) Act, 1970, came into operation on 19th June, 1970. Since then the general prohibition had been lifted for five days during the Chinese New Year festival of 1971, and for another five days for the same festival in 1972. However, sections of the public did not co-operate or observe the conditions under which fire- crackers and fireworks might be discharged. The result was further tragedies. In 1971, nine persons were injured during the Chinese New Year festival. In 1972, during the Chinese New Year, members of the public became more bold in their disregard of the conditions under which firecrackers could be discharged. The result was more tragedies. There were 376 incidents reported about crackers being indiscriminately fired outside the stipulated paces and times. But for vigorous police action, which resulted in 37 arrests, the indiscriminate discharge of crackers would have been far more extensive. Despite police actions, the firing of crackers resulted in 26 persons being injured. In addition, two unarmed policemen were brutally attacked, and seriously injured when they tried to prevent a group of persons from letting off fire-crackers unlawfully. But for

Column: 1348

speedy surgical attention, their injuries would have been fatal. It is said customs die hard, but, it is a fact, they can cause deaths and make cripples.

    In view of the numerous breaches of the law and, even more important, the injuries and deaths resulting from the indiscriminate firing of crackers, the Government came to the conclusion that the only practicable solution left was a total ban on the possession or firing of crackers. Public sentiments, voiced through the newspapers, also called for such action. The present Bill was, therefore, introduced into Parliament on 21st March, 1972.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this Bill seeks to prohibit possession and discharge or letting-off of dangerous fireworks. As defined in this. Bill, dangerous fireworks includes fire-crackers, rocket fireworks, sand crackers, and such other fireworks which the Minister may, by notification in the Gazette, declare to be dangerous fireworks for the purpose of the Bill. The prohibition of possession of dangerous fireworks will not, however, apply to dangerous fireworks brought into Singapore in transit to other countries. Dangerous fireworks brought into Singapore for this purpose will have to be stored and dealt with as the Minister may direct.

    Any person who fails to comply with, or does any act contrary to the provisions of the Bill will be guilty of an offence, and may be punished with a fine not exceeding $5,000, or with imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or with both such fine and imprisonment.

    A police officer may arrest without warrant any person offending in his, view against any of the provisions of the Bill. Where dangerous fireworks are seized by a police officer, the fireworks may he disposed of as the Minister may direct.

    The Minister is empowered to make regulations to provide for the better carrying out of the provisions of the Bill. The Minister is also empowered to exempt any person or class of persons from all or any of the provisions of the
